item.title: Possessor(s) Review - The Devil You Know
item.content:encoded:
Possessor(s) is a new, rather awkwardly-titled Metroidvania from Hyper Light Drifter studio Heart Machine and indie powerhouse Devolver Digital, and it asks a very important question: what would happen if you found yourself sharing your brain with a demon?

Well, if this roughly 15-20-hour adventure is anything to go by, it turns out the answer is simple: you'd end up exploring a sprawling map, unlocking a suite of movement abilities, and fighting challenging bosses to progress a story about "codependency, loss, and survival", according to the devs.

I won't mince words at the outset: Possessor(s) offers a pretty bog-standard example of its genre, at least in gameplay terms, and I'm not entirely sure its narrative explores the aforementioned themes with enough depth or complexity to make it worth recommending either.

Possessor(s) Is Metroidvania By the Numbers

Despite an initially enthralling and fascinating setting - that of a city wracked by an apocalyptic event and still shuddering with the aftereffects of demonic invasion - Possessor(s) quickly settles into a rather rote Metroidvania rhythm.

If you've played the greats in the genre, like Hollow Knight (or, indeed, Castlevania: Symphony of the Night and Super Metroid), then you'll know what to expect here.

You'll gradually uncover a large, interconnected space full of themed areas, using newly-acquired traversal powers to reach hitherto-unavailable spaces, all while upgrading your combat abilities and survival capacity as you go.

It's not a particularly inspired take on the genre's typical gameplay conceits, and short of repurposing certain household objects as weapons - main character Luca will wield kitchen knives or a baseball bat rather than swords and spears - there's not much here that's pushing the envelope.

Of course, if you're looking for nothing more than a structurally unchallenging exploration-based platformer with some solid combat, that may not be a drawback for you, but if you're searching for any kind of innovation from your next Metroidvania hit, it's safe to look elsewhere.

Occasionally, the level design and art style will offer a diverting vista; you'll see a huge rupture in reality off in the background, for instance, or a series of floating office desks serving as platforms - but they're little more than set dressing for a very straightforward set of maps.

Combat in Possessor(s) Is Fun, but Repetitive

Solid is very much the word to describe the combat in Possessor(s). Heart Machine says the combat here contains "elements of platform fighters" like Super Smash Bros.

That's superficially true; you can juggle enemies and use a variety of different special attacks mapped to directional button-attack combos, and you can utilize an aerial dodge to keep yourself safe from nasty air attacks as well.

Honestly, though, I managed to make it through Possessor(s) without using most of the purportedly Smash Bros.-inspired moves at Luca's disposal. Early on, you'll unlock a parry (another increasingly overused mechanic, I think), and that'll carry you through the majority of Possessor(s).

For the most part, combat in Possessor(s) works pretty well, even if it fails to realize its full platform fighter potential.

Attacks land with a fairly satisfying heft (provided you're using a heavier weapon like the baseball bat), and knocking enemies against walls once their Sekiro-style poise is broken can be cathartic as well.

Unfortunately, Possessor(s) falls into a very common trap that's littered with the corpses of lesser Metroidvanias, and that's enemy variety. Put simply, you'll have seen every enemy on offer here within the first handful of hours, and the rest is essentially going through the motions.

As it progresses, Heart Machine's adventure will throw enemy variants at you, but they're little more than palette swaps with slightly more powerful attacks, so dodging or parrying them is a matter of dull course.

As is usually the case with games that struggle with enemy variety, Possessor(s) quickly devolves into muscle memory and tedium. I was begging for just one or two surprises to be hurled at me, but those surprises never came, and fighting the same set of possessed objects and animals became insanely repetitive.

Bosses are a slightly different matter; while there aren't many of them (and the sidequests reuse them in a borderline unforgivable manner), they're fun to fight and surprising in terms of their movesets. It's just the parts in between that feel boring.

Possessor(s) Has an Okay, If Uninspired Story

With combat and map exploration proving relatively unexciting, it's up to Possessor(s)' story to pick up the slack, but I don't know if it's ready to bear that kind of weight.

The characters here are endearing enough. Luca is a guarded young girl who's suddenly having to share her head with a demon, Rhem; they both need each other to survive at the outset of Possessor(s), so their relationship is initially an uneasy one.

From that setup, however, I'm sure you can quickly guess how things are going to end up. Could it be that Luca and Rhem will find a grudging respect for one another as they both learn about their respective histories?

That's the core problem with Possessor(s)' story in a nutshell; everything unfolds in an entirely obvious and predictable manner. A corporation called Agradyne, which manufactures batteries, is involved, and the fact that it's a corporation is literally all you need to know about its role in the narrative.

There are no twists or turns here, nothing that surprised or engaged me beyond the baseline level. At times, Possessor(s) revealed information to me that I think it thought was surprising, but I just rolled my eyes and said "well, obviously".

With that said, Heart Machine must have been doing something at least vaguely right, because I did have a tiny little lump in my throat at the story's conclusion. I don't think it's a particularly memorable tale, but it serves its purpose while it's around.

Possessor(s) Review | Final Thoughts

I enjoyed my time with Possessor(s) exactly enough to play through it once and then never think about it again. Its well-worn story is played out and unengaging, but its characters are fun enough to be around for exactly the time they're on screen and no more.

If you're a fan of Metroidvanias, like me, you'll quickly settle into the familiar Sunday-afternoon rhythm of Possessor(s), but those who don't like the genre or who are still coming down from the high of Silksong can safely wait before being possessed by this particular demon.

Possessor(s) was reviewed on PC with a copy provided by the developer over the course of about 15 hours of gameplay - all screenshots were taken during the process of review.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Riot Games Addresses Launch Issues with Riftbound: Origins
item.content:encoded:
Riot Games is addressing the launch issues of Riftbound: Origins. The debut launch of the official League of Legends trading card game has been marred by production and supply problems, negatively impacting the user experience.

Riot Games' Response to the Riftbound: Origins Launch

In an official blog post, Riot Games starts with gratitude at the reception to Riftbound: Origins. Furthermore, they confirm that the next set, Riftbound Spiritforged, is still on set to launch some time next year.

The focus on the post then shifts to the various production issues players have found while opening their first cards. For collectors, there was the fact that a certain percentage of booster packs were missing a rare card. Since each booster is supposed to contain 2 rares, this is a big deal. Worse still, it is an issue that won't be addressed until the game's third set.

The good news is you can get replacement rares. You simply have to fill out a form on UVS Games' website, then wait to see if you're approved. But if you bought packs in bulk, you may still miss out since the program is limited to 3 per person and 6 per household.

The second issue is a more subtle, textural issue regarding the cards themselves: Riot explains that due to the card stock used for printing, more wear was applied to the cutting tools, leading to burred, or rough, edges on the cards. The good news is this process has been mitigated and shouldn't be present for any future sets.

Issue three affecting the Riftbound: Origins launch is one most tabletop players may be familiar with: shipping delays. While Riot isn't specific on what is causing these delays, they do state they are dedicated to shipping out all of the first wave of product by the end of the week. To achieve this, products you bought will be shipping to you the minute they are available. So expect multiple packages.

Lastly, Riot will be making Proving Grounds cards more available. Certain promo packs containing many Proving Grounds cards (Legends, Champions, Signatures, etc.) will be available at Nexus Nights. These packs will contain foil versions of cards currently not available in Proving Grounds. There is currently no concrete info on price or availability.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. This… More about Tyler



https://techraptor.net/tabletop/news/riot-games-addresses-launch-issues-with-riftbound-origins

item.title: Marvel Rivals Season 5 Finally Introduces Gambit and Rogue
item.content:encoded:
NetEase has announced Marvel Rivals Season 5's release date, and the two heroes who will be joining the game's roster are none other than iconic X-Men Gambit and Rogue.

As revealed in a brand new trailer, the Cajun card sharp and the Mississippi power-sapper will be part of the hero shooter's fifth season, which will debut across all platforms on November 14th (so in just a couple of days!).

Usually, one of the two heroes arrives alongside the season's start, while the other will be added to the roster a few weeks into the cycle. We don't yet know which of the two will be the first to enter Marvel Rivals' arena, nor has it been officially revealed what class the two heroes will occupy.

The trailer for the two heroes, titled "Love Is a Battlefield", suggests that Marvel Rivals' fifth season will revolve around Gambit and Rogue's marriage, which is interrupted by "destiny". This prompts Gambit to set out on a journey to "win back the moment time itself stole from [him and Rogue]".

Marvel Rivals Season 5 follows on from the game's fourth season back in September, during which Daredevil and Angela were introduced. The former is a Duelist and the latter is a Vanguard, which might well suggest that Gambit will be another Duelist and Rogue will take the form of a Strategist.

You can check out the debut trailer for Marvel Rivals Season 5 right here. It doesn't give too much away about what you can expect from the season, but it does show off the designs for Gambit and Rogue, which are pretty nice.

Marvel Rivals Season 5 will arrive on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox Series X|S on November 14th, and you can also check the game out for free right now across all of those platforms.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
